msContents.summary: A Karaim translation of the Torah and the Haftarah

ab.title: Leviticus 11
ab.l: And the Lord spoke to Moses and to Aaron, sayingto them,
‘Speak to the children of Israel, saying,“These are the beings which you shall eat from all the animals that are on the earth.
All that parts the hoof, and has a split of hooves,|and| regurgitates cud among the animals, you shall eat it.

Just:you shall not eat this out of those that only regurgitate the cud andof those that only part the hoof: The camel: even though itregurgitates the cud, it does not part the hoof. It is uncleanto you.
And the rabbit: even though it regurgitates the cud,it does not part the hoof. It is uncleanto you.
And the hare: even though it regurgitates the cud,it does not part the hoof. It is uncleanto you.
And the pig, even though it parts the hoof and has a split of hooves, it does not chew the cud. It is unclean to you.
You shall not of their flesh, andyou shall not touch their carcass. They are unclean to you.
You shall eat this out of all that are in the waters: everything that has finsand scales in the waters, in the seas, and in the rivers — you shall eat them.
And all that does not have fins and scales in the watersand in the rivers, of all creeping animals of the waters and of allliving creatures which are in the waters, is detestable to you.
And they shall be detestable to you. You shall not eat of their flesh,and you shall find their carcasses repulsive.
Allthat does not have fins and scales in the waters: it is detestable to you.
And you shall find these repulsive out of the birds. They shall not be eaten,they are detestable: the eagle, and the bearded vulture,and the black vulture,
And the red kite, and thefalcon by its kind.
Every raven by its kind.
And the young of the ostrich, and the taḥmas, andthe seagull, and the hawk by its kind,
And the little owl, and the šalaḫ, and the long-eared owl,
And the white owl, and the pelican,and the carrion vulture,
And the stork,the heron by its kind, and the hoopoe, and thebat.
Every creeping animal of flying creatures that goes on four legsis detestable to you.
Just:you shall eat these of every creeping animal of flying creatures that goeson four legs: that which have knees above their feet,to leap by them on the earth.
You shall eat these out of them: the locust by its kind, and thesalʿam by its kind, and the ḥargol by its kind, andthe grasshopper by its kind.
And every creeping animal of flying creatureswhich have four legs, is detestable to you.
And you will become unclean by these. Everyone who touches the carcass of themshall be unclean until the evening.
And everyone who carriestheir carcass shall wash his clothes and be uncleanuntil the evening:
Every animal that parts the hoofand does not have a split |of hooves| and does not regurgitate its cud is uncleanto you. Everyone who touches them shall be unclean.
And all that walk on their paws among all the animalsthat go on four legs, are unclean to you.Everyone who touches their carcass shall be unclean until the evening.
And the one who carries the carcass of them shall wash his clothesand be unclean until the evening. They are unclean to you.
And this is unclean to you among the creeping animals that moveon the earth: the mole, and the mouse, and the|great| lizard by its kind,
And the gecko, and the monitor lizard, andthe lizard, and the |sand| lizard, and the chameleon.
These areunclean to you among the creeping animals. Whoever touches themafter they died shall be unclean until the evening.

And everything on which any of them falls after they diedshall be unclean, out of every wooden vessel orclothing or skin or sack, any vessel in whichwork is done, shall be put in water, and it shall be uncleanuntil the evening, and it will become clean.
And every earthen vessel,in the middle to which any of them falls: everything that is insideshall be unclean, and you shall break the vessel as well.
Of allfood which is eaten on which water comesshall be unclean, and all drink that is drunk in any kind of vessel shall be unclean.
And everything on which any part of their carcass fallsshall be unclean. An oven or stove, they shall be destroyed. They are unclean,and shall be unclean to you.
Just: a fountain or wellwith a concentration of waters shall be clean. But one who touches their carcassshall be unclean.
And if any part of their carcass fallson any sowing seed which is to be sown, it shall be clean.
But if any water is put on the seed, andany part of their carcass falls on it, it shall be uncleanto you.
And if any of the animals that are allowedfor you for food dies: he who touches the carcass of it shall be uncleanuntil the evening.
And he who eats of the carcassof it shall wash his clothes and be unclean until the evening.And he who carries the carcass of it shall wash his clothesand be unclean until the evening.
And everycreeping animal that moves on the earth is detestable.It shall not be eaten.

Everything that goes on a belly, and everythingthat goes on four legs as well as everything that has many legs among allcreeping animals that move on the earth: you shall not eat them,because they are detestable.
You shall not make your souls abominablewith any creeping animal that moves, and you shall not make yourselves uncleanwith them, so that your mind will be closed by them.
Because I am the Lordyour God. And you shall consecrate yourselves, and you shall be holy, because I am holy.And you shall not make your souls unclean with any creeping animalthat moves on the earth.
Because I am the Lordthat brings you up from the land of Egypt, to be God to you,and you shall be holy because I am holy.”’
Thisis the teaching of the animals and of the birds and of every livingcreature that moves in the waters and of every creature thatmoves on the earth,
To distinguishbetween the unclean and the clean, andbetween the animal that is eaten and the animal thatis not eaten.

app.note: K: Possibly a mistranslation; cf. Heb. בַּיַּמִּים ‘in the seas’.

Heb. תַּחְמָס of unclarified meaning: ‘an unclean bird of prey’ in Klein (1987: 698), ‘an unclean bird of prey, perhaps a species of owl’ in Koehler & Baumgartner (1985: 1025). | Translated as ‘nighthawk’ in KJ2000, ESV, and by Friedman (2003). | EKar. taḥmas in C is translated as ‘nighthawk’ by Jankowski & Aqtay & Cegiołka & Çulha & Németh (2019: II 142, 249).

Heb. שָׁלָךְ, a bird name of uncertain meaning: ‘probably the cormorant’ in Klein (1987: 662), ‘cormorant (?)’, ‘fish-owl (?)’ in Koehler & Baumgartner (1985: 978). | Translated as ‘cormorant’ in KJ2000, ESV, and by Friedman (2003). | EKar. šalaḫ in C is translated as ‘cormorant’ by Jankowski & Aqtay & Cegiołka & Çulha & Németh (2019: II 142, 249).

Heb. יַנְשׁוּף ‘long-eared owl’ (Koehler & Baumgartner 1985: 386; Klein 1987: 260). | See, however, ‘great owl’ in the KJ2000 and in Friedman (2003), and ‘short-eared owl’ in ESV. | EKar. janšuf in C is translated as ‘long-eared owl’ by Jankowski & Aqtay & Cegiołka & Çulha & Németh (2019: II 142, 249).

Heb. תִּנְשֶׁמֶתּ ‘a kind of owl, probably the white owl’ (Klein 1987: 709), ‘white owl’ (Koehler & Baumgartner 1985: 1035). | Translated as ‘white owl’ in KJ2000 and by Friedman (2003), translated as ‘barn owl’ in ESV. | EKar. tinšemet in C is translated as either as ‘white owl’ or as ‘barn owl’ by Jankowski & Aqtay & Cegiołka & Çulha & Németh (2019: II 142, 249).

Heb. קָאָת ‘pelican’ (Klein 1987: 559), ‘a species of owl (?)’ (Koehler & Baumgartner 1985: 817). | Translated as ‘pelican’ in KJ2000, and by Friedman (2003), translated as ‘tawny owl’ in ESV. | EKar. qaʾat in C is translated as ‘pelican’ by Jankowski & Aqtay & Cegiołka & Çulha & Németh (2019: II 142, 249).

Heb. סָלְעָם ‘a kind of locust’ (Klein 1987: 448), ‘edible locust’ (Koehler & Baumgartner 1985: 660). | Translated as ‘bald locust’ in KJ2000, ESV, and by Friedman (2003). EKar. salʿam in C is translated as ‘bald locust’ by Jankowski & Aqtay & Cegiołka & Çulha & Németh (2019: II 143).
Heb. חַרְגּוֹל ‘a kind of locust’ (Klein 1987: 230, Koehler and Baumgartner 1985: 331). | Translated as ‘cricket’ in KJ2000, ESV, Friedman (2003). | C: deest.

Heb. חָגָב ‘locust; grasshopper’ (Klein 1987: 207), ‘locust allowed for food’ (Koehler & Baumgartner 1985: 275). | Translated as ‘grasshopper’ in KJ2000, ESV, and by Friedman (2003). | EKar. ḥagav in C is translated as ‘grasshopper’ by Jankowski & Aqtay & Cegiołka & Çulha & Németh (2019: II 143).

Heb. צָב ‘a kind of a lizard’ (Klein 1987: 539), ‘thorn-tailed lizard’ (Koehler & Baumgartner 1985: 790). | Translated as ‘great lizard’ in KJ2000, ESV, and by Friedman (2003). | EKar. čab in C is translated as ‘great lizard’ by Jankowski & Aqtay & Cegiołka & Çulha & Németh (2019: II 143).

Heb. כֹּֽחַ ‘a kind of a lizard’ (Klein 1987: 274, Koehler & Baumgartner 1985: 430). | Translated as ‘monitor lizard’ in KJ2000, ESV, translated as as ‘spotted lizard’ by Friedman (2003). | EKar. kovaḥ in C is translated as ‘monitor lizard’ by Jankowski & Aqtay & Cegiołka & Çulha & Németh (2019: II 143).

Heb. לְטָאָה ‘lizard’ (Klein 1987: 299), ‘gecko’ (Koehler & Baumgartner 1985: 480). | Translated as ‘lizard’ in KJ2000, ESV, and by Friedman (2003). | EKar. letaʾa in C is translated as ‘lizard’ by Jankowski & Aqtay & Cegiołka & Çulha & Németh (2019: II 143).

Heb. חֹמֶט ‘lizard; a kind of a lizard’ (Klein 1987: 221), ‘all reptiles that are not defined’ (Koehler & Baumgartner 1985: 310). | Translated as ‘sand lizard’ in KJ2000, ESV, and by Friedman (2003). | EKar. ḥomet in C is translated as ‘sand lizard’ by Jankowski & Aqtay & Cegiołka & Çulha & Németh (2019: II 143).
